awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Proposal: EarthCube Integration: Accelerating Scientific workflowS using EarthCube Technologies (ASSET)
awd_abstract_narration:
A major need in the geosciences is to reduce the amount of time geoscientists spend on "data wrangling" tasks (finding, accessing, subsetting, gridding, processing, reformatting, visualizing) so that they can spend more time on complex scientific analysis. This project will develop a means for scientists to document and interact with all of the data management and analysis tools that they need to create a scientific result, and it will add tools to find common patterns in their work to help find tools that could reduce the time needed to produce the result. This work may also help to make moethods and analyses more transparent by providing the means to track the steps in creating a scientific result.

This project builds on relationships among cyberinfrastructure experts and geoscientists examine current scientific workflows and the integration of EarthCube tools.  The work will include a workflow sketching interface to specify the steps, dependencies, current tools, current duration, and other important aspects of a scientist's workflow.  As part of the proposed pilot project, the team will examine two geoscience use cases (hurricane risk and water resources) in detail and assign cyberinfrastructure experts to integrate EarthCube tools into these science workflows, to demonstrate the increases in productivity that are realized.  In addition, the team will conduct a workshop/clinic at a major geoscience conference to collect additional use cases from the community, where geoscientists will describe their workflows and receive personalized advice on the use of EarthCube tools.  If successful, the researchers may expand on this pilot project to conduct many more workshops at other venues and to map many more scientific workflows to corresponding EarthCube technologies.
org_div_long_name: Integrative and Collaborative Education and Research (ICER)

por.por_cntn:
A scientific workflow is the description of the steps required to achieve a scientific result. These workflows are important because scientists use them to reproduce and share the results of their work, allowing them to look for ways to make the scientific process more collaborative and efficient. In the Accelerating Science workflowS using EarthCube Tools (ASSET) project, we continued the development of a tool used to help scientists sketch their workflows called the Workflow Sketching Tool (WST). We conducted several workshops across multiple science disciplines to train scientists on the use of the tool and worked with them to shorten the time to science through the process of describing, sketching, and sharing their workflows with other scientists. Using this process, we successfully increased the efficiency of several workflows and shortened the time to achieve results. We demonstrated how well-documented workflows could significantly benefit projects with high personnel turnover ? for instance, students that are only attached to a project for a semester.  In addition, we added features to the WST requested by the community over the course of our project and built a library of workflow sketches to share with others.

 

Through ASSET and its workshops, we also initiated a new perspective related to shortening the time to science among many scientists, who then will carry these ideas into their future work. The long-term goal of increasing science efficiencies and describing workflows can also be of benefit to the process of reproducing prior results to enhance research. In addition, the ASSET team placed the Workflow Sketching Tool, captured workflows, training materials and other outputs in a public software repository so that it can be freely shared, used and developed by other scientists and technology experts.
